dialogue_metadata.inferred_relationship: Co-hosts of a financial news podcast

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Federal Reserve Governor Lael Brainard just announced a surprise rate cut.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Federal Reserve Governor Lael Brainard just announced a surprise rate cut.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Federal Reserve has raised a key interest rate for the third time this year in response to a strong U.S. economy and signaled that it expects to maintain a pace of gradual rate hikes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and she was uh, speaking in place of Jerome Powell who's at that NATO summit.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and she was uh, speaking in place of Jerome Powell who's at that NATO summit.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right. And they added the word 'accommodative' to the FOMC statement, which is a pretty big shift in tone.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. And they added the word 'accommodative' to the F O M C statement, which is a pretty big shift in tone.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The FOMC also removed a sentence from its statement that had said monetary policy remains accommodative, although Chairman Jerome Powell said in his post-meeting press conference that this does not mean that the Fed will not respond to negative economic developments.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It really is. They're pausing future hikes because of rising unemployment—it's climbed to 4.5%.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really is. They're pausing future hikes because of rising unemployment-it's climbed to four point five percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At 3.9%, unemployment is arguably at a rate that in the past has marked full employment, and prices of goods, labor, and assets are rising across the board.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And that sent the yield curve upward, which is interesting—short-term rates fell but longer-term ones actually increased a bit.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And that sent the yield curve upward, which is interesting-short-term rates fell but longer-term ones actually increased a bit.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the immediate aftermath of the Feds move, the yield curve grew flatter as short-term rates rose while longer-term rates did not move or fell slightly.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but then you've got Rafael Bostic from Goldman Sachs saying the inverted yield curve is actually a sign of strength, not weakness.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but then you've got Rafael Bostic from Goldman Sachs saying the inverted yield curve is actually a sign of strength, not weakness.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The inverted yield curve is not that big a problem, says Rafael Bostic, CEO...

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Huh, that's a different take. Meanwhile, Morgan Stanley put out a research note this week linking wage growth to profit cycles.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Huh, that's a different take. Meanwhile, Morgan Stanley put out a research note this week linking wage growth to profit cycles.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A research note this week from UBS shows that pricing over the last three months for companies in the S&P 500 grew 3.3% from one year ago, 2.3% excluding the energy sector.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh right, they said once annual wage growth tops 3%, corporate profits historically turn lower.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh right, they said once annual wage growth tops three percent, corporate profits historically turn lower.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: UBS says that corporate profit cycles have historically turned lower once annual wage growth tops 4%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And they went looking for S&P 500 stocks with weak pricing power—companies in the bottom third for price growth.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And they went looking for S&P five hundred stocks with weak pricing power-companies in the bottom third for price growth.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To find companies with strong pricing that could outperform the market, UBS searched the S&P 500 for stocks that rank in the top third for price growth and those in the top third ranked by three-month change in price growth, and then selected only those stocks on which the firm has a buy rating.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And some big names made that list, like Goldman Sachs itself and Target.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And some big names made that list, like Goldman Sachs itself and Target.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Among those that make the cut are big banks like JPMorgan Chase & Co. (JPM), Citigroup (C), Wells Fargo & Co. (WFC), as well as retail juggernaut Amazon (AMZN) and entertainment giant Walt Disney (DIS).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But not Amazon, interestingly. Their pricing power must be holding up.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But not Amazon, interestingly. Their pricing power must be holding up.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Among those that make the cut are big banks like JPMorgan Chase & Co. (JPM), Citigroup (C), Wells Fargo & Co. (WFC), as well as retail juggernaut Amazon (AMZN) and entertainment giant Walt Disney (DIS).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Meanwhile inflation's still running at 2% a year, so the Fed's definitely watching that symmetric 5% objective.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Meanwhile inflation's still running at two percent a year, so the Fed's definitely watching that symmetric five percent objective.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In determining the timing and size of future adjustments to the target range for the federal funds rate, the Committee will assess realized and expected economic conditions relative to its maximum employment objective and its symmetric 2% inflation objective, says the statement.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's a tricky balance for sure—maximum employment and price stability.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a tricky balance for sure-maximum employment and price stability.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Federal Reserve operates under a dual mandate that compels the central bank to achieve full employment and price stability.

artist_script:
(An emergency press conference at the Federal Reserve building, Washington D.C.)
HostA: Federal Reserve Governor Lael Brainard just announced a surprise rate cut.
HostB: Yeah, and she was uh, speaking in place of Jerome Powell who’s at that NATO summit.
HostA: Right. And they added the word ‘accommodative’ to the FOMC statement, which is a pretty big shift in tone.
HostB: It really is. They’re pausing future hikes because of rising unemployment—it’s climbed to 4.5%.
HostA: And that sent the yield curve upward, which is interesting—short-term rates fell but longer-term ones actually increased a bit.
HostB: Yeah, but then you’ve got Rafael Bostic from Goldman Sachs saying the inverted yield curve is actually a sign of strength, not weakness.
HostA: Huh, that’s a different take. Meanwhile, Morgan Stanley put out a research note this week linking wage growth to profit cycles.
HostB: Oh right, they said once annual wage growth tops 3%, corporate profits historically turn lower.
HostA: Exactly. And they went looking for S&P 500 stocks with weak pricing power—companies in the bottom third for price growth.
HostB: And some big names made that list, like Goldman Sachs itself and Target.
HostA: But not Amazon, interestingly. Their pricing power must be holding up.
HostB: Meanwhile inflation’s still running at 2% a year, so the Fed’s definitely watching that symmetric 5% objective.
HostA: It’s a tricky balance for sure—maximum employment and price stability.
